cab.content: confidential.(57) 9713th April, 1957WILTON PARKMemorandum by the Chancellor of the exchequer have no objection to the expenditure of a certain amountof public money on educating and influencing Europeans. But I am not convinced that we need to keep a large and expensive countryhouse running all the year round for the purpose. One canenvisage vacation courses at Oxford or Cambridge or many other forms of activity in this field which would be equally effectivewhile costing far less. And there are private bodies like theEuropean League for Economic Co-operation, which would welcome the opportunity of furthering these aims.COPY NO.cabinet. This case exemplifies the difficulty of achievingeconomies. Everyone agrees with the principle of reducingGovernment expenditure. But of what value is the principle unless it is applied ?3. The Foreign Office firmly agreed last July that. WiltonPark should close down in August, 1957. All plans have been basedon this decision and I suggest that it should stand.P.T.Treasury Chambers, S.W.1.12th April, 1957.
